transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: All right, this is an MTF with Trent and Amber. Take one. Time code is 11-13-39-40-41. Marker. Love it. You're good to go, Tegan. Thank you. Trent, can you tell me what today is?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Today is September 1st. I'm not looking at you.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: I just felt like. Tegan, why don't you slide back?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Today is September 1st, Poppy's first heavenly birthday. However, it's only been six months since his passing and I've been working on this rock to put down at the poppy tree. And yeah, this is kind of what we're doing. So I was wanting to get it done by today. But it just says poppy, plain and simple, but I'm not like a stone etcher, engraver. I have my Ph.D. in so many things in life, but I don't have it in this. And this has been, it's like six hours for five letters. Yeah. Had to count that out.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: Are anniversaries like today particularly difficult when you're reminded of it more? Maybe just like he's on your mind for an anniversary.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Today's not really. I don't dwell in salt over Poppy's passing. Now, if I was 16 and Poppy was 55, it would be different. But I'm 48 now. He was 90. There was no losses. So there's moments like if I hear a song, some of his gospel music or something, or songs, or, you know, think back or see a picture, you know, I smile. I don't cry and things. I smile, and it's a good feeling. But I guess that's the great part about living a good life and such an honest life like he did is – It makes it easy for all of us. So I don't, like today, you know, I like to do certain things to remember it and to do things in honor of him, such as plant this massive tree and then do this rock. But, yeah. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Well, I think ultimately it has a lot to do with that Poppy lived such a long, fulfilled life. And, you know, Trent was very, and all of us were very fortunate to have so many years with Poppy. It's very different than if you, you know, like I lost my mom super early in life. That's an example of... meeting and my kids were me and it was like man she's not like she's not here you know where fortunately with poppy we you know we had all of our children and our children are grown and um you know sure we're having great grandchildren now for poppy and things like that but that's he got to see layton yeah then that's kind of the way life goes um

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: But... The most blessed thing with Papa is not only did he live 90 years, but he didn't get sick. He didn't have a terminal illness. He didn't... He got tired.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: He didn't suffer.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: No, he got tired. And so... And I think it helps all of us. It helps the kids. And like Amber says, Mamaw, Amber's mama... I don't want to say she missed out, but we all missed out so many milestones. Emma coming home, kids graduating from high school, things like that, that she was not able to be a part of. Other grandkids, Amber's brothers and sisters. Other weddings. Other weddings and things like that. A new grandbaby, which would be her great grandbaby. It's different. So, you know, that's not the case. Poppy got to see... all of his grandkids grow up. Ella would be the youngest, but Ella was 17 when Poppy passed away. So not that that's grown up, but yeah, all the childhood fun stages he was able to be a part of.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: Can you tell me about the process of how you

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: So the process for the rock was Amber and I went to a landscape shop and picked out a rock.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Fortunately, this young man, he just picked it up and set it on the back of the trailer. This rock probably weighs 150 pounds. It's real heavy. And I came home and just typed up some different fonts until I found one I like. And then I did different sizes and I cut them out and brought them out here and I sized them up on the rock. And funny enough, the font is font style Georgia, which is, I didn't realize that until I'd already made the choice. So it's font size Georgia, font style Georgia. Georgia, but size, we had size 50, 100, 150, 175, and then 200. And we chose 175. And then we cut it out with an X-Acto knife, and I traced it out with a super fine point Sharpie and started carving it out from there. Engraving. Engraving. See, I don't know much about that.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Engraving. And you spent several hours engraving and... Getting dusty. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: And then... Went through a lot of little diamond tips.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: And then, you know, was thinking that initially thinking that we would color it, the inside to kind of make it stand out better. But fortunately, they did a little his birthday or today's date, I guess I should say, which is his birthday. But today's date and tried out the color. And, you know, we all kind of decided that I think we should leave it with no color right now. See how it weathers. and see if we want to add something.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: He was a super simple man.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: He liked all sorts of foods. Everything. We pretty much liked everything except peas and chicken livers.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: He even liked fruitcake. He wouldn't have wanted a fancy rock.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Who likes fruitcake? He loved it and felt like everybody else needed to have fruitcake.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: He only ate fruitcake. It was a seasonal thing. During the holidays. During the holidays, he would eat fruitcake. During the holidays, there's a place down in Georgia, South Georgia, where he would order a case. He would get 24 loaves of Claxton's fruitcake. It comes wrapped in red wax paper.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Yeah, and it's probably been there for decades.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: They could have used it in Hurricane Katrina to stop the levees.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: But you would show up and he'd go there. And he would. Y'all need to try a piece. Come here, Jonah. Alex, eat a piece of this.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: You don't know what's good.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: That's what he would say. You don't know what's good. And I'd say, no, you don't know what's good because that can't be good. You had to take small bites because you choked.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: So you're moving the rock down, and I will say I was less stressed today than I was when you guys were doing the tree, but when you did that first step, I gasped. Yeah. Because it was so loud. I said, hey, did you have a backup plan if it, like, fell and started rolling?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Let go of it. So being in, going back to my work experience, I don't want to say I've always been quick on the hand, but I've always, I've always thought ahead and planned ahead, and that comes a lot with being a little personal and figuring out how you're going to do this because you don't want to always ask somebody because then they don't think you can do everything that they can do. So I've always had a plan of thinking ahead, and it does not bother me in the least to let go of something before I get hurt because I'll either trash it and throw it away or go buy another one. but I'm not going to get hurt. So this rock coming down off these steps, this rock weighs 150 pounds. It's not like super heavy, but it's like picking us up. Everybody thinks we weigh 60, 70 pounds. No, I'm 140 pounds, 145 right now. But we're very dense. We're very small, compact, very dense. So we feel like we weigh 200. That rock feels like it weighs 500 pounds, but it's just compact and dense. And toting it down those steps was, yeah, that first step was like, wham! But if I would have, like I told everybody out there, and I told Emma, you want to make sure you keep your chin out of the way because your chins and your teeth and your tongue all lined up.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: And Poppy would have heard some language today that he would not have approved of should that hand truck handle would have flown up and hit me in the chin.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: The hat would have came off.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: The tongue would have been bleeding. The rock would have been in the bottom of the pool.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Oh, God.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: And I'd have been like, that's not where he wanted to be.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: But that's where he's staying.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: We baptized him today. Sorry, Poppy. I love you. But you know, I ain't got to explain this. I'm not getting you off the bottom of the pool. I'll drain that pool.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: You'll drain it.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: I'll drain the pool and take the hand trucks down the ramp. Yeah. The slope of the pool. Then we'll figure out how to get the hand truck up the slope.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: Or you could use your CPAP with your snorkel. Yes. We'd have you in a full scoop of gear.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: So, I, yeah, I... The plan was just to get the rock down the steps. And then I was going out there, and I'm like, I'm not doing all this work. Even though he's my dad, I'm not doing all this work. So I told Emma, hey, come over here and take the rock down the hill. I promise you you don't have to push it. It'll take you. And she did very good. It was kind of like a crab crawl she did.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: That's okay, though.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: She didn't end up on her face. She was like in four-wheel drive mode. She was down-geared, geared down, yeah.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: So when you're down there and you're saying a few words about your dad and just about how his legacy lives on through you guys, and I think it also very much lives on through your kids, especially like in the past when I'm seeing Emma and Alex, like how much they stepped up around the house with Clayton and Brandon. Does it make you really proud to see those traits reflected in your kids?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: So, you know, the fact that we really try to... um, lived through Poppy's legacy and how Poppy served and helped others. And, you know, Trent and I are very much that way. And now we see it with our kids and the way we've raised our kids. You know, Emma and Alex have really stepped up in helping Layton. And then also, you know, with the tragic accident with our nephew, Brandon, they have helped countlessly going to, you know, the trauma hospital with us. And, you know, just doing everything from helping Brandon, sitting beside Brandon, feeding Brandon, whatever is needed, and being there with us when we're there with him at the hospital. It's proud. It definitely is a proud moment for Trent and I because we know that You know, they have watched it as they have grown with Trent and I and the way we have lived our life. And now they're, you know, paying it forward.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Amber and I have done this hospital stays and hospital sits and visits many times, even with our own kids, weeks at a time. And they... Now at an adult age, 18 and 19 years old, they understand it. And hopefully we're teaching them, you know, one day later should Amber and I be in the hospital, that they're going to stay bedside with us and give us the support. And that's what Poppy would have done. That's what he would have expected. What we're doing is what he would expect us to do and he would ask us to do, even if he was unable to. So Brandon was Poppy's oldest grandson. So, yeah, it's a tragic accident, but slowly we are getting it figured out and getting Brandon back to good health. It's just we've got a really long road and We were explaining to the kids down there, I mean, maybe standing beside Poppy's tree and doing this rock today wasn't the best time to talk about it, but I guess you had everybody's attention and it was just one of those moments and we explained to them that Brandon is now out of the trauma hospital after eight weeks and he's in rehab and he's doing good in rehab. We still have a while to go in rehab, but Brandon's going to need a place to go. And during all this time, Amber and I have taken care of all of Brandon's business affairs, his medical affairs, and we've had to terminate his lease and where he was living and whatnot because there's no need to continue making payments and spending all those monies and dollars when it's going to be a year or two years before Brandon's able to live on his own again. And sometimes you have to draw a line in the budget and do what's best. Brandon also cannot live by himself. He cannot live by himself emotionally, most importantly. But physically, for a while, he's not going to be able to live by himself. Brandon is a single parent. He has a 14-month-old son. And he loves that little boy tremendously. And we have arrangements set up with a family friend of ours that is taking care of Brandon's son, Braden. And everything has... worked out great and has been a blessing. But again, it all comes back to everybody, family, family time and, and family working together and your close friends. We all have friends, but everybody should have those friends that they can count on and depend on without asking. And we have those friends and Brandon has a few of those friends as well. And, Amber and I have always taught all of our kids, all five of our kids, how important it is to keep your family in your circle and keep your close friends in your circle. Not all of them always listen to us. And there's times like this when it's important that you're going to need those family.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Well, I feel like when this accident happened and Trent and I were notified, and I walked into that trauma room the first time, My immediate reaction, obviously, was, and I had seen a photo of Brandon, but it just didn't do the situation justice. Walking into that room and knowing that Brandon has no parents, has no siblings.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: He has friends, but the friends are not able to just drop everything and care for him. I immediately think about my children. And what would I want to be done for my children if Trent and I were not here? And if something like this, because the accident that happened to Brandon can happen to any of us, and something like this happened to any one of my children, I would hope that somebody would step up. Hopefully their siblings would step up and do what Trent and I are doing for Brandon. And that is what, you know, I know Poppy would have done. Because Poppy knew Brandon's situation. And, you know, there were times in the past that Nana and Poppy would step up and take care of Brandon when he was in other situations. But that, I think, was definitely... That moment for me was just... I mean, it was overwhelming because... I'm a mom of five kids, and this could have definitely happened to one of my children, and I would just hope that the other four would rally around if Trent and I weren't here, would rally around and take care of their sibling. And, you know, in Brandon's situation, he didn't have that option.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: So a little back history on Brandon and how Brandon is connected to the Johnston family. Nan and Poppy had a foster daughter years and years and years ago. They were contacted by an orphanage, a domestic orphanage here in Georgia, about a dwarf teenage girl who was placed up for foster care and for adoption at a young age. Nan and Poppy looked into adopting her and making her a part of our family. They never were able to adopt her because some of her family would not give up complete rights. Unfortunately, as the system, the family continued to want to draw a check on the child. Nana Poppy fostered this daughter her entire life. She was my oldest, oldest sister. She passed away two years ago. Brenda's father passed away seven years ago. And like Amber said, Brenda's the only child. So they consider him an adult orphan. Only thing that Brandon has is us. And when we found out about the accident, that was when we had to kick in. When we found out about the accident, Brandon had already had emergency surgery. He was lifelighted from the scene. He died.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: He was lifelighted from the scene to the trauma hospital, the major trauma hospital in Atlanta. They quickly moved him to... Well, he died. Well, he died. He coded twice. He died twice. They then moved him to a heart hospital because he had torn the aorta off his heart. He went in for emergency heart surgery. And as the heart surgeon told us, she does not know how. She does not know why. She does not know any reason as to him making it through that surgery. But he did. And so at that point is when we started. He had finished. His chest was still wide open. That is when Trent first saw him. And then I came back. The next morning, and his chest was still open. They had to leave his chest open for about three days. And then they went in. They told us that they were going to try to close the chest. But he, you know, had a long road ahead of him. They knew that he had basically on his right side, he was broke all the way down.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: So Brandon's accident was on a Friday night. He was going to visit some friends, and it was very bad weather, and Brandon was in a small fender bender.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: A gentleman had ran a yield sign, and Brandon hit him. Brandon got out to look at the accident, and when he got out to look at the accident, another car came around the wreck and struck Brandon's body at 51 miles an hour. He was lifelighted from the scene. He had the number two aorta torn off the top of his heart. He had three brain bleeds, a broken orbital, fractured eyes, eight right- Fractured neck. Fractured neck, eight right broken ribs, seven fractured ribs on the left side. A shattered right leg.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Fractured left leg.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Fractured left leg. Torn liver. Torn spleen. And in the midst of all that, he caught pneumonia.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Went septic.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: He went septic.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Had internal bleeding.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: And underwent eight blood transfusions.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: But he is now at a physical rehabilitation hospital and doing remarkably well. Almost like too well. I'm like, yo, dude. But he is doing very well. Physically. I mean, we still have... We say that because we came from, you know, literally laid on life support for 21 days and, you know, just all this. But... he still has a long, long way to go to gain his independence. And, you know, I don't think life will ever be the same for him. I don't think, you know, the way he does things, the way he... His previous jobs, you know, they've told us that, you know, it's just not going to be happening for him.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: He has to live a more cautious life now.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: His biggest goal is to...

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Be able to take care of his son. Be able to take care of his son. Independently.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Yeah. And that's what we're going to help him do.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: So, to bring it all back to Poppy, I guess, since that's what today is for. Revere it all for a little bit. Trent, in as busy as your guys' life is, is it really meaningful to you that you were able to take this moment, even if it's just 15 minutes, with your family and your kids to remember your father on his birthday?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Today, you know, is Poppy's birthday. And... This whole rock was just something I wanted to do a while back to put down at the tree. But then I realized, oh yeah, I've never done this before, but this is my first family birthday for one of my parents. So I did knew that I had plenty of time to work on this rock. It's small, but it wasn't an easy little task. It was to try to make it nice and keep it detailed. So, yeah, this all just circles back around. And we were always, Amber and I were always told by Nan and Poppy and from them all the time that, well, it'll just work out like it should be. Don't worry. Things will just work out. And we used to think, God, I get tired of hearing that. Oh, my gosh, I get tired of hearing that. And now here we are. Things will just work out like they should. And today it worked out.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Even though we're super busy and we have 47 different things in different directions that we need to go in today. We have to go see Brandon. I have a presentation. I mean, it just is never ending. We still take the moment, take the time to honor Poppy on his first heavenly birthday.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: He was before all of us.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: Yeah. Let's do 30 seconds.
